ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: none
We had breakout rooms, discussions with guest speakers, conversations with officers, powerpoints, presentations, etc.
No other modes
The class was combination of lecture and discussion section styles.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: General navy knowledge
I learned about Navy scenarios and steps to take to approach dealing with them as an officer.
I learned more about the Navy and aspects of being an officer.
I learned the basics of the Navy and military in general.
Knowledge and skills essential to our development as leaders and as future officers in the United States Navy.
I gained insight into the experiences of Navy personnel, and learned how to analyze ethical scenarios that may be applied in real life to the Navy and Marine Corps.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was so long I had a really hard time focusing at the end, especially because of the virtual format
I thought the organizers did a great job, and I thought lab was a worthwhile experience.

Strengths: instructor involved students in course discussions and encouraged them to speak.

Weakness: none
Overall an engaging, yet low-commitment course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Make it shorter during COVID, it can go back to normal length during normal times
Zoom is never ideal, but they made the best of it. In-person lab would obviously be better.
I liked the breakout rooms/sessions discussion, and I liked that the officers were rotated through different breakout rooms so that we could hear from several of them over the course of the lab.
Nothing could really be improved; they did the best they could given the circumstances. The course did a good job with making lectures easy to follow.

This course translated well during the COVID-19 pandemic. Normally, we would be sitting in an auditorium, hearing guest speakers talk, and on Zoom it is not much different. What's even better is that Zoom breakout rooms provides ROTC students with the opportunity to discuss ethical scenarios and hold competitions. This is very easy to do online.

Class is 7am on Fridays, which can be a pain, but is also great since it frees up the rest of Friday for other classes that may interest you.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: only for ROTC
It's required for NROTC, but I have found it helpful as I hope to pursue a career in the Navy.
No, its really only needed for students considering a career in the military after graduation.

Yes! Even if you are not in NROTC, you just sit back, relax, and listen to prominent speakers and their cool experiences in the Navy/Marine Corps. If not, you just chill in a discussion room, talking about ethical scenarios and preparing your brain for analyzing real-life leadership situations. It is a very low-commitment class (although even as a civilian you must be there 10 min early to not face the wrath of the officers.) This Fall 2020 semester, former Chief of Naval Operations Admiral Richardson even dropped by to speak.
